meanings.definition: Convert (an image or graphic) into a vector format.
meanings.sent1: I will vectorise the logo to make it scalable.
meanings.sent2: Graphic designers often vectorise images for better quality.
meanings.sent3: Why did the computer try to vectorise a photo of a cat wearing glasses?
meanings.sent4: Her artistic talent allowed her to effortlessly vectorise any drawing.
meanings.sent5: The process to vectorise the map was time-consuming but worth it for accuracy.

meanings.definition: To represent (a quantity) as a vector.
meanings.sent1: In physics, we often vectorise forces to analyze their direction.
meanings.sent2: Mathematicians vectorise data to simplify complex calculations.
meanings.sent3: The teacher asked the students to vectorise the number of apples in the basket.
meanings.sent4: She could easily vectorise emotions into colorful illustrations.
meanings.sent5: To vectorise the speed of the car, we need both magnitude and direction.

meanings.sent1: The software can quickly vectorise any text document.
meanings.sent2: Scientists often vectorise data for clearer visualization.
meanings.sent3: The magician tried to vectorise a rabbit into a vector, but it hopped away.
meanings.sent4: His ability to vectorise ideas into action made him a great leader.
meanings.sent5: To vectorise the concept, we need to break it down into simpler components.
